A new organization, the American
Independence league, has contacted
a group of students as to the possibility of forming a chapter in the
Hopkins. The organization is headed
by H C Van Rensselaer, of Princeton
university.
In a letter to Thomas McElhiney,
Arthur Machen, a league member,
discussed the reasons for the founding
of the league and its aims.
The American Independence league
was formed by a group of undergraduates of Princeton, Harvard and
Massechusetts Institute of Technology. These boyq felt that college
students, "who stand most to lose
both in the immediate and in the distant future, in the event of United
States entrance in the European
war," should not remain inactive.
The league is dedicated to revealing, strengthening, and expressing the
determination of the people of the
United States to keep us out of war.
The organization, in other words, is a
means of expressing the feeling of
the people in regard to our entrance
into the war. The colleges are to be
used as "hubs of activity." The
league intends to reach business clubs,
women's oganizations, and youth
groups.
A preliminary convention was held
in New York City on October 22.
Representatives of 20 colleges attended. A working declaration was
drawn up and an executive committee of 5 was elected.
Many colleges all over the country
have started similar movements although they have different names.
The University of California has the
Youth Rally For Peace and Northwestern has the Collegiate Front For
Peace.
The American Independence league
desires to solidify these three groups
into one, and get a large collective
expression over a large area.
Anyone interested in this movement
may contact either the Liberal Club,
or McElhiney. They will give any
further details desired.

With the settlement of the absentee
voting question so that students absent because of University activities will be permitted to vote, the
Student council hopes it has permanently solved the long-debated issue, it was learned from Carrington
Williams, council president, this week.
Settlement of policy on the voting
question occurred at last Friday's
meeting of the council. Also taking
place at the meeting was the election of Charles Flagle, Senior councilman to the post of vice-president.
In the recent Senior Class elections,
precedent was broken by the permission of 12 proxy votes cast by
students on a University-sponsored
trip. These votes were sufficient to
swing the election.
Under the new plan, however, a
list of students who are to be called
away on activities such as geology
tirps will be secured from the faculty
prior to the election. These students
will be notified that they can, if they
so desire, vote in advance by contacting personally a member of the
Student council who will be stationed
at a designated point in Levering
hall.
"This innovation," remarked Williams, in comment, "is properly called
asbentee voting, rather than proxy
voting, since the voter casts his ballot directly with the council."
